questions.text: 1. Penicillin is most likely to kill the bacteria in which phase of the bacterial growth curve shown below?
questions.solution:
The log (logarithmic) phase, also known as the exponential phase is when rapid cell division occurs. β -Lactam drugs, such as penicillin, act during this phase because the drugs are effective when cells are making peptidoglycan (i.e., when they are dividing).

The first is the lag phase, during which vigorous metabolic activity occurs but cells do not divide. This can last for a few minutes up to many hours. The stationary phase occurs when nutrient depletion or toxic products cause growth to slow until the number of new cells produced balances the number of cells that die, resulting in a steady-state. The final phase is the death phase, which is marked by a decline in the number of viable bacteria.

questions.text: 2. A 55-year-old patient presents with painful lesions that appear as in the image below. What is the nature of the virus responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image showing confluent, red, pustular lesions in a single dermatome is highly suggestive of Herpes zoster, which is caused by the varicella-zoster virus- a double-stranded DNA virus. 

Initial infection with the virus causes chickenpox, associated with disseminated vesicular rash and fever. Upon resolution of the acute infection, the virus remains latent in a cranial nerve or dorsal root ganglia. Herpes zoster infection or shingles is a segmental eruption due to the reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus from the dorsal root ganglia. An earlier infection with varicella is essential before zoster can occur. 

The first symptom of zoster is usually pain. It may also be accompanied by fever, headache, malaise, and tenderness localized to areas of one or more dorsal roots. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and the nasopharynx. The thoracic dermatomes are most commonly affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.

Zoster is a self‐limiting infection, but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post‐herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

Pearl PM2006: Enveloped and non-enveloped viruses

  Non-enveloped viruses Enveloped viruses
DNA viruses

Parvovirus

Adenovirus

Herpes virus

Hepatitis B virus

Poxvirus
RNA viruses

Picornavirus

Astrovirus

Reovirus

Calicivirus

Hepatitis A and E virus

Hepatitis c virus

Rubella virus

Chikungunya virus

Dengue virus

Japanese encephalitis virus

Kyasanur Forest disease virus

Zika virus

questions.text:
3. A 21-year-old woman came with fever, headache, and vomiting for 3 days. On examination, her temperature is 101 F, pulse rate is 108 bpm, and BP is 80/60 mm of Hg. A maculopapular rash is seen over the trunk and extremities. She has neck stiffness and flexion of the neck causes flexion of the hips and knees. Which of the following media is used as transport media for the causative organism?

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination:

* Reduced glucose

* Increased protein

* Increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of meningococcal meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis, for which Stuart’s medium is the transport medium. 

The scenario of a patient with fever, maculopapular rash, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Brudzinski's sign) with CSF showing reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocyte levels is typical for meningococcal meningitis. A nasopharyngeal swab from the patient is held in a Stuart transport medium till it is plated.

Composition of Stuart Medium:

* Sodium glycerophosphate

* Sodium thioglycollate

* Calcium chloride

* Methylene blue

* Agar

Characteristics of Stuart medium: This medium is a chemically defined, semisolid, non-nutrient medium that prevents microbial proliferation. Because of its composition, the medium ensures that microorganisms present are able to survive for a long period of time.

Sodium thioglycollate produces a reduced environment to improve the recovery of anaerobes. Methylene blue acts as an oxidation-reduction indicator. Calcium chloride maintains the permeability of bacterial cells, and sodium glycerophosphate maintains the pH of the medium. The medium appears colorless in the reduced state and blue in the oxidized state.

Meningococcal meningitis commonly presents with non-specific symptoms like fever, vomiting, headache, and irritability. Other features of bacterial meningitis include neck stiffness, photophobia, decreased consciousness, seizures, and focal neurologic signs. A non-blanching rash (petechial or purpuric) develops in the majority of cases.

Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial hemorrhages. 

Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

Treatment: Ceftriaxone and cefotaxime provide empirical coverage for N. meningitidis, but penicillin G is preferred for susceptible strains. Rising penicillin resistance warrants susceptibility testing; if resistant, cefotaxime or ceftriaxone is used. A 7-day IV course is adequate for uncomplicated cases.

Chemoprophylaxis for close contacts (those who are exposed to oropharyngeal secretions) includes rifampin for 2 days (600 mg 12-hourly in adults, 10 mg/kg in children >1 year). In pregnancy, give a single dose of azithromycin (500 mg) or IM ceftriaxone (250 mg).

Other options:

Options A, B, D- Cary Blair medium, Venkatraman Ramakrishnan medium, and autoclaved seawater are used as the transport mediums for Vibrio cholerae

Pearl PM0106: Organisms and their transport media

questions.text: 4. A 60-year-old malnourished, HIV-positive man with fever, night sweats, weight loss, and productive cough shows the given sputum microscopy finding. How is this infection acquired?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing pneumonia in a HIV-positive patient and microscopy showing modified acid-fast positive and branching, filamentous rods is suggestive of Nocardia asteroides which is transmitted through inhalation of contaminated soil.

Nocardia are gram-positive, strict aerobes found particularly in the soil and are found to produce lung infections, mostly in the immunocompromised. Nocardia infection is frequently exogenous (Option B) . Person-to-person transmission (Option A) or transmission from animals (Option C) does not occur. They are gram-positive and are also positive in Kinyoun's acid-fast staining technique.

Clinical manifestations: Cutaneous infections may lead to local abscesses, cellulitis, or lymphocutaneous lesions. Pleuropulmonary nocardiosis usually manifests as pneumonia, lung abscess, or other lesions resembling tuberculosis. Symptoms may include fever, night sweats, weight loss, chest pain, cough with or without sputum production, and shortness of breath. Hematogenous spread from the lung is most frequently to the brain. Other common sites include skin, kidneys, bones, muscles, and eyes, but almost any organ can be involved. 

Treatment - Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Cotrimoxazole) is the drug of choice. Close differentials to Nocardia include:

* Actinomyces species that causes Actinomycosis is endogenous in human beings. They are gram-positive filamentous bacteria similar to Nocardia but are not acid-fast.

* Nocardia mimics tuberculosis in clinical presentation, but tuberculosis is transmitted by an infected person. 

* Nocardia species infect animals, but transmission from animals to human beings does not take place.

Pearl PM1786: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  


 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.


C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: 5. A precipitation test yielded a negative result in a patient with suspected syphilis. However, all his symptoms, signs, and risk factors are strongly suggestive of syphilis. Which of the following reasons best explains this outcome?

choices.text: The patient lacks antibodies against syphilis.
The antigen-antibody ratio was optimal for precipitation.
Sample antigen concentration exceeds antibody binding sites.
Non-specific test antigen used, leading to cross reactivity with other antibodies.

questions.solution:
The sample antigen concentration exceeding the available antibody binding sites explains the outcome of the test in the given question.

The patient's symptoms suggest syphilis infection, but the negative precipitation test result indicates a mismatch between antibody and antigen levels. The most likely explanation for the negative test result is excessive antigen concentration in the patient's serum sample, exceeding the available antibody binding sites (post-zone phenomenon). With excess antigen, antibody binding sites become saturated, preventing lattice formation and visible precipitation. This leads to a false-negative result.

The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions and agglutination reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. Precipitation occurs when a lattice consisting of alternating antigen and antibody molecules is formed.



The prozone phenomenon is caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. There is weak/absent precipitation, giving a false-negative test. In the zone of equivalence, antigen and antibody are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs. Lattice formation is enhanced. Post-zone phenomenon is due to the presence of excessive antigens in the test system. There is weaker/absent precipitation.

The prozone phenomenon and post-zone phenomenon can give rise to false-negative results in precipitation reactions. This can be overcome by making serial dilutions of serum, thereby optimizing the concentrations of antigens and antibodies in the test system.

Other options: 

Option A: This can be ruled out since the patient exhibits clear symptoms.

Option B: This is unlikely because a negative result suggests insufficient precipitation.

Option D: Cross-reactivity usually leads to weak positive results due to non-specific binding with other antibodies. A completely negative result, as in this case, is less typical.

questions.text: 6. A middle-aged man from West Africa developed sudden onset of fever and chills, severe headache, cough, sore throat, muscle, and joint pain. This was followed by abdominal pain and vomiting. The electron microscopy image of the likely causative agent is given below. To which bioterrorism category does it belong?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the electron microscopy image are suggestive of Ebola virus infection, which is a category A bioterrorism agent.

Ebolaviruses are long, thread-like viruses. They belong to the genus Filovirus. Three strains of the Ebola virus have been recognized: the Zaire strain (EBO-Z) with a case fatality rate of 90 percent, the Sudan strain (EBO-S) with a case fatality rate of 50 percent, and the mild Reston strain (EBO-R).

The incubation period is 3 - 25 days. The infected people develop biphasic syndrome with a 1 to 2-day relative remission. The first phase resembles influenza, characterized by sudden onset of fever and chills, severe headaches, cough, myalgia, pharyngitis, arthralgia of the larger joints, and development of a maculopapular rash. The second phase is characterized by abdominal pain with vomiting and/or diarrhea, chest pain, edema, and coma. Hemorrhagic manifestations such as subconjunctival injection, epistaxis, hematemesis, hematuria, and melena are typical.

It spreads from person to person through direct contact with body fluids such as blood, urine, sweat, semen, and breast milk. Diagnosis is made through the detection of Ebola virus antigen, RNA, or antibodies in the blood. Treatment includes supportive care with aggressive fluid and electrolyte replacement

Bioterrorism is the deliberate release of an agent by attackers that causes one or more of a variety of diseases. Category A (High risk) poses a threat to national security and has the ability to cause social disruption. Examples include Ebola, anthrax, botulism, plague, smallpox, and tularemia.

Pearl PM0152: Bioterrorism Agents

Description Characteristics Examples
Category A

High mortality rate

Capacity to get disseminated

Social disruption

Requires specialised public health resources

 

Bacillus anthracis

Clostridium botulinum

Yersinia pestis

Variola major

Francisella tularensis

Ebola and other hemorrhagic fevers

Lassa fever and other arenaviruses

 
Category B 

Minority priority agents

Moderately well disseminated

Moderate morbidity and low mortality

Require enhancement of CD and diagnostic capacity

Coxiella burnetti

Burkholderia mallei

Burkholderia pseudomallei

Ricin toxin

Cryptosporidium parvum

Salmonella typhi

Chlamydia psittaci
Category C

Could be engineered for mass dissemination

Readily available

questions.text:
7. A 37-week primigravid mother presents to you in active labor. Her serology done 2 weeks before revealed the following findings. What is the best step in the management of the newborn?

HBsAg positive
HBeAg positive
Anti-HBc IgG positive


HBIG- Hepatitis B immune globulin

choices.text: Single-dose HBIG and vaccination after 1 week

questions.solution:
The best step for an infant born to a hepatitis B carrier mother is single-dose HBIG and routine vaccination.

This pregnant woman, having HBeAg and HBsAg positive with anti-HBc-IgG positive, has a chronic hepatitis B viral (HBV) infection or is in a chronic carrier state. Both of the above scenarios put the infant at risk of HBV transmission. The recommended management is to give a single dose of hepatitis B immune globulin immediately and the first dose or routine vaccination within 12 hours of birth.

HBIG confers passive immunity and is also given to persons exposed to HBV percutaneously or by contamination of mucosal surfaces, along with the HBV vaccine. HBIG does not interfere with the antibody response to the hepatitis B vaccine. This combined procedure is ideal both for postexposure prophylaxis of persons accidentally exposed to blood known to contain the hepatitis B virus and for the prevention of the carrier state in the newborn babies of carrier mothers.

Interferon alfa, entecavir, and tenofovir are first-line treatments indicated for patients with chronic active hepatitis to prevent the progression of liver fibrosis. It is not indicated as prophylaxis for babies born to seropositive mothers.

Pearl PM1680: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection



 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA

Acute HBV - Early-phase,
high infectivity

 + - + - IgM +++
Acute HBV -Window phase - - +/- +/- IgM +
Acute HBV - recovery phase - + - +/- IgG +/-
Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++
Chronic HBV, low infectivity + - - + IgG +
HBV infection in the recent past - + - - IgM -
HBV infection in the remote past - - - +/- IgG -
Post-vaccination - + - - - -

questions.text:
8. A 10-year-old boy from Tamil Nadu was rushed to the emergency department with a headache, fever, and blurred vision, followed shortly by unresponsiveness to verbal commands. He is suspected to have mosquito-borne viral encephalitis. Which of the following is not true about the likely causative agent?

* It is transmitted by Culex vishnui

* Man acts as the reservoir

* Herons act as an amplifier host

* The majority of the infections by this agent are asymptomatic

* The Kolar strain-derived vaccine is administered intramuscularly.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Japanese Encephalitis, for which statements 2 and 3 are wrong.

The given clinical scenario of mosquito-borne viral encephalitis in a patient from an endemic region (Tamil Nadu) is suggestive of Japanese encephalitis (JE). Humans are the dead-end hosts for the virus (Statement 2). Herons act as reservoir hosts (Statement 3), and pigs act as the amplifier hosts.

JE follows bird-arthropod-human transmission. The disease is transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui, which are common in India (Statement 1). Humans are the dead-end hosts, pigs are the amplifier hosts, and Ardeid birds like herons and egrets are reservoir hosts. Ardeid are medium to large wading birds found mostly in coastal areas. The herons are long-legged freshwater and coastal birds in the family Ardeidae.

It is characterized by the sudden onset of fever and vomiting, which later progresses to encephalitis. Signs of encephalitis, such as convulsions, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium, appear after 1-6 days. Up to 50% of survivors may have neurological or psychiatric sequelae. Infection during the first or second trimester may even result in fetal mortality.

It is the leading cause of childhood neurological viral infection in India. It was first reported in Vellore in India and continues to be active in states of Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, and other states, causing illness mainly in children. An important point of note is that the majority of the infections are, in fact, asymptomatic, and >300-500+ asymptomatic infections occur for every symptomatic case of JE(Statement 4). 

No specific treatments have been found to benefit patients with JE, but hospitalization for supportive care and close observation is generally required. Treatment is symptomatic. Rest, fluids, and the use of pain relievers and medication to reduce fever may relieve some symptoms. The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from human dwellings, and vaccinating pigs.

JENVAC is a new inactivated Vero cell culture-derived JE vaccine manufactured and used in India. It is a Kolar strain-derived vaccine. The recommended dose is 0.5ml, which is given intramuscularly (statement 5) at the left anterolateral aspect of the midthigh, 4 weeks apart starting from 1 year of age.

Although a booster dose is recommended at a later period, the appropriate time for booster dose administration is not clear. Previously, the SA-14-14-2 live attenuated vaccine given subcutaneously was widely used and is being replaced by the JENVAC vaccine now.

The image below shows the life cycle of the Japanese B encephalitis virus.

questions.text: 9. A 26-year-old female patient comes to your clinic with a rash shown in the image below. The onset was insidious and the rashes are mildly itchy. Wood's lamp shows pale yellow fluorescence. Microscopy of the causative organism would show which of the following morphological features?

choices.text: Sclerotic cells with brownish cell walls

questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and image are of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. It is caused by fungi belonging to the Malassezia species which on microscopic examination shows the presence of yeasts and hyphae in skin scrapings.

Malassezia species are lipophilic fungi. They cause degradation of lipids producing acids like azelaic acid that inhibit tyrosinase, resulting in hypopigmented patches. 

Malassezia species that are commonly involved in Tinea versicolor are-

* Malassezia globosa

* Malassezia sympodialis

* Malassezia furfur

Clinically, Tinea versicolor presents with hypopigmented patches or hyperpigmented or reddish patches due to inflammation. It commonly affects the upper trunk, upper arms, neck, and abdomen. They are mildly itchy if at all and have fine scales that are branny/furfuraceous.

Under Wood's lamp examination, the lesions show a pale yellow fluorescence. On KOH mount and microscopy the Malassezia species appear as short unbranched, non-pigmented hyphae and spherical cells. This is also called the ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ appearance or ‘bananas and grapes’ appearance. 

Treatment involves selenium sulfide, topical or oral azoles. 

The image attached below shows the classic spaghetti and meatballs appearance on KOH mount.



Other options: 

Option A: Sclerotic cells with brownish cell walls are observed in chromoblastomycosis.

Option B: Sulfur granules are observed in mycetoma infection.

Option D: Yeasts with capsules are characteristic of cryptococcosis.

Pearl PM1761: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

* Yeast

* Yeast-like

* Molds

* Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding

* Oval to round forms

* Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.



 

Yeast like:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding or binary fission

* Spherical or oval forms

* Pseudohyphae may be seen.

* Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.



 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

* Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate

* Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.

* Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.



 

Dimorphic fungi

* Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.

* Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.

* Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

Pearl PM0260: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: pale green

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

questions.text: 10. A farmer came to the outpatient clinic with a cauliflower-shaped mass on the foot, which developed after a minor injury. A histopathological image of the lesion is given. Identify the pathognomonic structure in the slide given below.
questions.solution:
The pathognomonic structure in the slide is a sclerotic body. 

The given clinical scenario of a cauliflower-shaped mass developing after a minor injury is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis. The histopathological image showing round, dark brown bodies is sclerotic bodies.

Chromoblastomycosis is more commonly seen in tropical areas among agricultural workers and woodcutters who walk barefoot. The fungus enters the skin by traumatic implantation. Patients present with warty cutaneous nodules on the feet and lower legs. Species of the fungal genus Fonsecaea are implicated as the causative agents.

Diagnosis is by demonstration of sclerotic bodies in tissue sections. Sclerotic bodies appear as round or irregular, dark brown bodies with septae. 

The condition can be managed with amphotericin B or thiabendazole. For small lesions, surgical excision is the therapy of choice.

Pearl PM0144: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

1. Bacterial Inclusion Bodies 

Disease/Bacteria  Inclusion bodies 
Granuloma inguinale, Klebsiella granulomatis Donovan bodies

Trachoma, Chlamydia trachomatis Halberstaedter-Prowazek bodies
Lymphogranuloma venereum, Chlamydia trachomatis Miyagawa’s granulocorpusles
Diphtheria, Corynebacterium diptheriae Babes-Ernst granules


 

2. Viral Inclusion Bodies

Rabies Negri bodies
Vaccinia, variola (smallpox) Guarnieri bodies
Variola (smallpox) Paschen bodies
Molluscum contagiosum Henderson-Patterson bodies
Fowlpox Bollinger bodies


* Intra-nuclear Inclusion Bodies 

  Inclusion bodies  Disease/Virus
Cowdry type A Lipschutz inclusions Herpes Virus
Torres bodies Yellow fever
Cowdry type B Basophilic inclusions Adenovirus
Acidophilic inclusions Poliovirus


* Both Intra-nuclear and Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies 

Disease/Virus  Inclusion bodies

3. Inclusion Bodies in Parasitic Infections

questions.text: 11. A 40-year-old male who visited the flood-affected area in North America presents with low-grade fever, chest pain, cough, and haemoptysis. Radiological examination of chest reveals cavity formation with lung abscess. Culture from the abscess at 37°C, shows the appearance given in the image. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Thick-walled yeasts can show Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.
Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores
This disease can mimic pulmonary tuberculosis
It is caused by a dimorphic fungus

questions.solution:
The statement "thick-walled yeasts can show Mickey Mouse or pilot wheel appearance" is not true regarding the condition of pulmonary blastomycosis. In pulmonary blastomycosis, thick walled yeast cells with broad based budding is seen.

The given clinical scenario with a history of travel to the flood-affected area in North America suggests a diagnosis of Pulmonary blastomycosis caused by Blastomyces, which is a dimorphic fungi. The condition is also called North Amerian Blastomycosis. Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding give rise to the figure of 8 appearance.

However, at room temperature, the fungus culture shows filamentous growth with septate hyphae, containing many round or oval conidia, and at times chlamydospores. This is why Blastomyces is termed as a dimorphic fungus, with different morphologies in vivo and at room temperature. Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores, usually present in wood debris or soil close to rivers or subject to flooding.

Blastomycosis can present in three forms: primary cutaneous, pulmonary, and disseminated. Pulmonary blastomycosis is very similar to pulmonary tuberculosis. There may be no symptoms, or there may be low-grade fever, chest pain, cough, and hemoptysis. Occasionally, erythema nodosum develops. The pulmonary lesion may resolve, or there maybe cavity formation with lung abscess.

It is Paracoccidioides that shows a characteristic yeast-like appearance with multiple peripheral budding resembling a pilot's wheel, or, when only two buds are around the mother cell, resembling a Mickey Mouse head.

Pearl PM2370: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings





1. Histoplasma:

* Mycelial growth showing spherical spores, which are large (8-10 μm size) and thick-walled, with tubercular projections.

* Tiny oval yeast cells (2-4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 



2. Blastomyces: Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 



3. Coccidoides: Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20-80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 



4. Paracoccidioides: Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: 12. A patient presents with complaints of fever and right upper quadrant pain, following consumption of certain aquatic plants. Blood test reveals eosinophilia and stool sample reveals the egg of a certain parasite, as shown in the image. Which of the following best describes the adult form of the microbe involved?

choices.text: Arise from the excystation of cercariae
Need two hosts for the completion of sexual phase
Reside in the vesical and pelvic plexus of veins
Have the potential to cause obstructive jaundice

questions.solution:
The history along with the given image suggests infection with Fasciola hepatica, which produces eggs that are ovoid, operculated and bile stained. Chronic infection with this parasite is known to cause obstructive jaundice.

Fasciola hepatica, also called the sheep liver fluke, is a trematode that passes its life cycle in one definitive host and two intermediate hosts :

* Definitive host(for sexual phase): Sheep, goat, cattle, and man.

* Intermediate hosts(for the asexual phase): Snails of the genus Lymnaea and Succinea, which are the first intermediate hosts. Encystment occurs on aquatic plants, which act as the second intermediate host.

Mode of infection - The definitive host, sheep and man get the infection by the ingestion of metacercariae encysted on the aquatic vegetation. The metacercariae excyst in the duodenum, pierce the gut wall and reach the liver and biliary passages, where they mature into adult worms. These worms lay eggs in the biliary passages, which are shed in the feces.

The clinical features include fever, tender hepatomegaly, right upper quadrant pain, obstructive jaundice and eosinophilia. Diagnosis is made by the detection of eggs in stool and aspirated bile. 

Oral triclabendazole (10 mg/kg once) is the treatment of choice.

The life cycle of Fasciola hepatica is shown in the image below:

questions.text: 13. A 36-year-old male patient presented to the ophthalmology outpatient clinic with complaints of redness, pain, and watering of the left eye for the past two days. He also complained of difficulty in vision. A careful slit-lamp examination revealed the following finding in the anterior chamber. Which of the following is true regarding the causative organism?

choices.text: Sheathed microfilaria with 2 nuclei at the tail
Sheathed with nuclei extending up to the pointed tail tip.
Unsheathed with a blunt tail tip free of nuclei.
Sheathed with a pointed tail tip free of nuclei.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of an adult worm of Loa Loa in the anterior chamber of the eye. The microfilariae of Loa loa are sheathed with nuclei extending up to the pointed tail tip.

Loiasis is a skin and eye disease caused by the nematode worm Loa loa. Humans contract this disease through the bite of a deer fly or mango fly, the vectors for Loa loa. The adult filarial worm migrates throughout the subcutaneous tissues of humans. Calabar swellings are temporary foci of inflammation that appear as Loa loa wanders through the subcutaneous tissues. They are up to 3 cm in size and are also called fugitive swellings because they disappear in a few days, only to reappear elsewhere.

Subconjunctival migration of an adult worm to the eyes can occur frequently and is thus called the African eye worm. It causes painless edema of the eyelids and proptosis. 

The microfilaria of Loa loa have diurnal periodicity and are usually found in day blood samples. It is known to migrate to the skin and other tissues at night, which causes itchiness commonly reported in ‘night guards’ infested with the disease.

Loiasis is diagnosed by characteristic history and presentation with eosinophilia and elevated levels of antifilarial antibodies. It can also be  diagnosed by detection of microfilariae in the peripheral blood, isolation of the adult worm from the eye or a subcutaneous biopsy from a swelling. PCR-based assays for the detection of L. loa DNA in blood is another technique that can be employed to diagnose loiasis. 

Onchocerciasis caused by Onchocerca volvulus is a differential diagnosis in this case. The following points differentiate the two. 

* Ocular onchocerciasis may affect any part of the eyeball and may cause keratitis, iridocyclitis, choroiditis, glaucoma, and optic neuritis and cause blindness (commonly known as ‘river blindness’). Loa loa, on the other hand, mainly involves subconjunctival tissues.

* Onchocerca is usually smaller in size than Loa loa.

* The adult worm of Onchocerca is found in subcutaneous nodules, while the microfilariae may be seen in the skin and eyes. The adult worm of Loa loa is seen in the conjunctiva and connective tissue, while microfilariae are found in the blood.

* The pattern of microfilaraemia in onchocerciasis is opposite to that in Loa loa. It is non-periodic, where the number of microfilariae maintains a constant level during the day and night. 

* The microfilariae are unsheathed with a blunt tail tip free of nuclei. 

Other options:

Option A: A sheathed microfilaria with 2 nuclei at the tail is characteristic of Brugia malayi and it causes filariasis.

Option D: The microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti are sheathed with a pointed tail tip free of nuclei and it causes filariasis.

Pearl PM1766: Filarial worms and their morphology

questions.text: 14. A pregnant woman is bitten by the following insect and develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash. There is no history of contact with infected animal hide or skin. A positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins is observed. What will be the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for scrub typhus in pregnancy is azithromycin.  

The given clinical scenario with a positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins, and the life cycle of a trombiculid mite (which acts as the vector) are suggestive of scrub typhus. The drug of choice for a case of scrub typhus during pregnancy is azithromycin. For other patients, the DOC is doxycycline.

Doxycycline, due to its teratogenic effects on dentition and bone growth, is avoided in pregnancy. Azithromycin or rifampin is administered as an alternative for patients allergic to doxycycline and in pregnancy. An alternative in pregnant women and patients allergic to doxycycline is chloramphenicol.

Scrub Typhus is also known as chigger-borne typhus which is caused by Rickettsia or Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is a trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

Serologic assays such as indirect fluorescent antibody, immunoperoxidase, enzyme immunoassays, and rapid lateral flow tests are the main methods for diagnosing scrub typhus, while PCR from eschar samples is useful though less effective with blood. Treatment includes doxycycline, azithromycin, or chloramphenicol, with combination therapy of doxycycline and azithromycin offering better outcomes in severe cases.

Scrub typhus gives positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins. Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains OX 19, OX 2 and OX K. The basis of the test is sharing an alkali-stable carbohydrate antigen by some Rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus.

DISEASE

OX 2

OX K

questions.text: 15. A male sewer worker had an on-and-off fever for 2 weeks, followed by jaundice, and purple-blue spots on his skin. He developed hematuria and neck stiffness soon after that and was found to have deranged hepatic and renal parameters. He succumbed to death. A hepatic tissue section is stained as shown below. What special stain has been used to visualize the specimen?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is consistent with a diagnosis of leptospirosis caused by Leptospira which are best visualized in tissue sections by staining using Levaditi's silver impregnation method.

Leptospirosis is caused by contact with the blood or urine of an infected organism in a contaminated water body. It is a type of zoonosis and can affect all mammalian species. Rats are well-known reservoirs. 

The clinical picture varies from mild disease to severe fatal disease, referred to as Weil's disease. Signs and symptoms of leptospirosis include fever, jaundice, meningismus, hemorrhage, and acute kidney injury. Faget sign (temperature pulse dissociation) is also seen.

A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis. In the acute phase of the disease, leptospires can be seen in blood in the first week of infection. This is done with darkfield microscopy or immunofluorescence.

Leptospires should be treated with IV penicillin. Ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, or doxycycline are alternatives for the treatment of severe leptospirosis.

Other options-

Option A: Albert's stain is used to demonstrate Corynebacteria with metachromatic granules. On staining with Albert stain, it shows delicate green bacilli with purple-blue metachromatic granules. 

Option C: Gomori’s methenamine silver stain is commonly used for staining fungal cell walls. It stains the fungal wall black.

Option D: Loeffler’s methylene blue is used to stain the granules of Corynebacteria a bluish-purple color.

Pearl PM1786: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  


 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.


C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: 16. A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Gram-positive cocci in clusters were isolated from the food samples collected at the party. The isolated organism formed beta-hemolytic colonies on sheep blood agar. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the organism most likely to cause these symptoms?

choices.text: Negative mannitol fermentation test is seen.
It is catalase-positive and coagulase positive.
Forms small, pink  colonies on MacConkey agar due to lactose fermentation.

questions.solution:
The statement that negative mannitol fermentation test is seen is false.

The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 1 to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food. Gram-positive cocci in clusters that form beta-hemolytic colonies on sheep blood agar indicate that the organism is Staphylococcus aureus. It shows a positive mannitol fermentation test.

The common sources of infection are foods that are not cooked after handling. These include ham, poultry, potato or egg salad, mayonnaise, cream pastries. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.

They are coagulase-positive, catalase-positive, hydrolyse urea, reduce nitrates to nitrites, etc

Enterotoxin produced by Staphylococcus is a preformed toxin that is heat-stable (Most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile). Around eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known. Most of the cases are caused by type A toxin. The toxin is believed to act directly on the autonomic nervous system rather than on the gastrointestinal mucosa. The toxin is antigenic in nature. They are superantigens and are potent activators of T-lymphocytes.

 Another organism causing food poisoning within the same time period of 2-6 hrs is Bacillus cereus. Staphylococci produce catalase, which converts hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen and produces bubbles, as shown below.



The image below shows positive and negative coagulase test.



The below image shows the golden yellow pigment of Staphylococcus on nutrient agar.



Pearl PM2350: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source
1–6 hrs incubation period  
Staphylococcus aureus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Ham, poultry, potato, cream pastries, mayonnaise
Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice
8–16 hrs incubation period  
Clostridium perfringes Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Beef, poultry, legume, gravies
Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period  
Vibrio cholerae Watery diarrhea Shellfish, water
Salmonella species Inflammatory diarrhea Beef, poultry, eggs
Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli Watery diarrhea Salads, cheese, meats
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli Bloody diarrhea Raw milk, raw vegetables, apple juice
Campylobacter jejuni Inflammatory diarrhea Poultry, raw milk
Shigella species Dysentery Potato, egg salad, lettuce
Vibrio parahaemolyticus Dysentery Molluscs, crustaceans

questions.text: 17. A small scale dairy owner follows a pasteurization technique of heating the milk at 63°C for 30 minutes. Which of the following disease can be caused in his customers by the organism that can survive this method of pasteurization?
questions.solution:
The pasteurization technique described in the above question is of the Holder method and Coxiella burnetti survive this method of pasteurization. It is the causative agent of Q fever.

Pasteurization can be done by heating the Milk  at either 

* 63°C for 30 minutes: the Holder method or

* 72°C for 15–20 seconds: the flash process

Once heated appropriately, the milk is cooled quickly to 13°C or lower. 

All the non-sporing pathogens are killed except Coxiella burnetti, which may survive in the Holder method.

Other options :

* Trench fever is caused by Bartonella quintana.

* Enteric fever includes typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi and paratyphoid fever caused by Salmonella paratyphi A, B and C.

* Oroya fever is caused by Bartonella bacilliformis.

Pearl PM0814: Methods of Sterilization and Disinfection

  Spectrum Uses
1. Heat    
Hot air oven All Glasswares, sterilizing powders, oils, swabs and dressings
Autoclaving All Linen, surgical instruments, laboratory ware, media and pharmaceutical products
Boiling Most pathogens, some spores Metal tools, rubber or plastic equipment, cloth 
Pasteurization Vegetative bacteria Beverages, plastic hospital equipment
2. Ethylene oxide gas All Heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, artificial valves, fabrics, respirators, cardiac catheters, books
3. Radiation    
UV All Limited value due to poor penetration, can be used for plastic syringes, catheters, and laboratory cabinets
Ionising All Surgical supplies, food
4. Chemicals    
Alcohol Vegetative bacteria, viruses some spores Skin disinfection, hand washing
Hydrogen peroxide Viruses, vegetative bacteria, spores and fungi High-level disinfectant, antiseptic for wounds and discharging ulcers
Chlorine Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi To disinfect water
Iodophors Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi, lethal to spore-bearing organisms Skin disinfection, disinfect blood culture bottles and medical equipment
Crude phenol Gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but only slowly effective against spores and acid-fast bacteria. Disinfection of faeces, mopping floors and cleaning drains.
5. Glutaraldehyde   All Endoscopes, bronchoscopes
6. Quarternary ammonium compounds Most bacteria, fungi, lipophilic viruses  General cleaning

questions.text: 18. A man sustained a crush injury and presented with severe pain, soft tissue crepitus, discoloration, and bullae in the affected area. The discharge from the affected site was positive for Nagler's reaction. Which of the following toxins produced by the causative organism is the basis of Nagler's reaction?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens. α-toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens forms the basis of Nagler's reaction.

The α-toxin of C. perfringens has lecithinase activity. When C. perfringens is grown on a media containing egg yolk with the α-antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralization of α-toxin. This is known as Nagler's reaction.



Other Options: 

Option B: Beta and epsilon (Option C) toxins have lethal and necrotising properties.

Option D: Theta toxin is an oxygen-labile hemolysin antigenically related to streptolysin O. It is also lethal and a general cytolytic toxin.

Pearl PM2187: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

* Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax

* Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique

* VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)

* Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)

* Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

* Widal test- typhoid

* Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever

* Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae

* Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis

* Coombs test

* Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis

* Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis

* Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

* Wasserman reaction(syphilis)

* Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

* Schik test for diptheria

* Anti streptolysin O test

* Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text: 19. A 28-year-old primigravida is diagnosed with an acute infection of an organism at 10 weeks of gestation. The life cycle of the organism is shown below. Which of the following can be used to prevent vertical transmission of the infection to the fetus in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given life cycle with both schizogony and gametogony in the definitive host cats is suggestive of Toxoplasma gondii. Spiramycin can be administered for cases of acute infection in early pregnancy to reduce vertical transmission to the fetus.

Spiramycin can be administered for cases of acute infection in early pregnancy to reduce vertical transmission. It does not cross the placenta and, therefore, cannot be used to treat an infected fetus. Pyrimethamine-sulfonamide (to be avoided in the first trimester) is used when a fetal infection is confirmed or in maternal infections after 18 weeks. (Option B)

Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to transplacental transmission from an affected pregnant woman or during the delivery of the fetus. The severity is higher when the infection is acquired in early pregnancy. The characteristic triad consists of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and diffuse intracranial calcifications. Other manifestations include hydrops fetalis, intrauterine growth retardation, prematurity, peripheral retinal scars, persistent jaundice, and mild thrombocytopenia.

The diagnosis is made by the detection of IgM anti-toxoplasma antibodies (IgG crosses the placenta). IgM immunosorbent agglutination assay (ISAGA) and IgA ELISA are the most useful diagnostic tests.

Other options:

Option A: Suramin is effective for the early stages of T. brucei rhodesiense infection, where the CNS is not involved, as it cannot penetrate the blood-brain barrier.

Option D: Doxycycline is not used to treat toxoplasmosis and is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects on bones and teeth.

Pearl PM2373: Infective form and diagnostic forms of various protozoa

Parasite Infective form Diagnostic form
Entamoeba histolytica Mature quadrinucleate cyst Trophozoites, quadrinucleate cyst
Giardia lamblia Quadrinucleate cyst Trophozoites, cyst
Trichomonas vaginalis Trophozoites Trophozoites
Naegleria fowleri Trophozoite Trophozoite in CSF
Acanthamoeba Trophozoites and cysts Trophozoite in CSF
Leishmania donovani Promastigote amastigotes in macrophage
Trypanosoma cruzi Metacyclic Trypomastigote Trypomastigote
Trypanosoma brucei Metacyclic Trypomastigote Trypomastigote
Balantidium coli Cysts Cysts
Plasmodium spp. Sporozoites Schizont, immature trophozoite, mature trophozoite, gametocyte
Babesia spp. Sporozoites Maltese cross form
Toxoplasma gondii All 3 morphological forms - oocyst, tachyzoite, bradyzoite Tachyzoites, tissue cysts
Cryptosporidium parvum Sporulated oocyst Sporulated oocyst
Cyclospora cayetanensis Sporulated oocyst unsporulated oocyst
Isospora belli Sporulated oocyst unsporulated oocyst

questions.text: 20. An unconscious patient is brought to the emergency room. You plan to intubate the patient using the instrument shown in the image below. What is the criticality of the instrument according to the Spaulding classification and what level of disinfection is needed for this instrument?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image above is a Macintosh blade. It is a semicritical instrument according to the Spaulding classification and requires a high level of disinfection.

Semi-critical items are those that come in contact with mucous membranes or minor skin breaches (non-intact skin) and they need a high level of disinfection.

Spaulding classification is used to classify the devices used on the patient, which determines the type of method selected for disinfection or sterilization. The three categories of the devices are critical, semi-critical, or noncritical

The system also established three levels of germicidal activity for disinfection (high, intermediate, and low).

Spaulding Classification:

Body Contact Disinfection requirements FDA device Class
Intact skin Low level Non-critical

Mucous membranes/ non
intact skin

 High level Semi-critical
Sterile body cavity Sterilization Critical


Pearl PM0818: The Spaulding Classification

The Spaulding classification classifies medical devices according to the degree of risk of infection if they are contaminated.

Device

Description

Examples

Disinfection

Non-critical device

Lower risk of infection as the device comes in contact with intact or normal skin.

Stethoscope, walls, furniture, BP cuff, etc.

Intermediate/low-level disinfectant.

Clean, dry and store for future use.

Semi-critical devices

Lower risk of infection as these devices come in contact with mucosa and do not penetrate into sterile areas of the body.

Fiber-optic endoscopes, laryngoscopes, bronchoscopes, cystoscopes, vaginal specula, etc.

High-level disinfectant to be used after proper cleaning or sterilization by heat.

Critical devices

High risks of infection as these devices come in contact with sterile areas of the body like blood.

Needles, cardiac catheters, implants, intrauterine devices, urinary catheters, etc.

High-level disinfectant is indicated with sterilization with heat, ethylene oxide, etc.
